text: Multiple Choice Which of the following combinations will not tile a flat surface?

a. regular heptagons

b. equilateral triangles

c. regular hexagons

d. squares
Multiple Choice Which of the following combinations will tile a flat surface?

a. regular heptagons and equilateral triangles

b. regular octagons

c. regular pentagons and regular hexagons

d. regular hexagons and equilateral triangles
Multiple Choice Which of the following combinations will tile a flat surface?
A right triangle has one right angle and two acute angles. Without measuring the angles, what is the sum of the measures of the two acute angles? Explain your reasoning.
The sum of the acute angles is 90°. The triangle angle sum (180°) minus a right  angle (90°) is 90°.
Without measuring, find the measure of the angle labeled x in each regular polygon.
Write an equation and find the measure of each angle labeled x.
The figure below is a regular dodecagon. It has 12 sides.
• (a). What is the sum of the measures of the angles of this polygon?
• (b). What is the measure of each angle?
• (c). Can copies of this polygon be used to tile a flat surface? Explain.
This figure will not tile a flat surface,  because no integer multiple of 150  equals 360, the angle sum at each  vertex of a tiling pattern.
Kele claims that the angle sum of a polygon he has drawn is 1660°. Can he be correct? Explain.
The number 1,660 is not an integer  multiple of 180, so it cannot be correct for the angle sum of any polygon.
Fine the measure of each internal angle and the sum of the internal angles for the following concave polygons.
A figure is called a regular polygon if all sides are the same length, and all angles are equal. List the members of the Shapes Set that are regular polygons.
Regular polygons include: A, B, C, D, E, and F
Suppose in-line skaters make one complete lap around a park shaped like the quadrilateral below.
What is the sum of the angles through which they turn?
Suppose the skaters complete one lap around a park that has the shape of a regular pentagon.
• (a). What is the sum of the angles through which they turn?
• (b). How many degrees will the skaters turn if they go once around a regular hexagon? A regular octagon? A regular polygon with n sides? Explain.
The answer to all questions is 360°  because they will make exactly one  complete turn as they skate around any polygon
A class was asked what convinced them that the sum of exterior angles in any polygon is 360°. Here are three different points of view.
What are the pros and cons of each argument?

The aim of this task is to get students to reflect on mathematical practices that  provide justification for discoveries. There  is something to be said for the strategies  proposed as convincing by each group—empirical evidence is very often the first  step toward a generalization and, for  most people, it provides practical intuitive  confidence in a result. The limitation is, of  course, that drawing and measurement  are inexact and they only give inductive  evidence of what might be true. The thinking that infers an angle sum of 360°  from imagining the turns that one makes  in a complete circuit of a polygon is both intuitively appealing and logically convincing. The argument from a prior result about interior angles and deduction of connected exterior angles is perhaps more mathematically logical (assuming that the interior angle result is well established), but the path from the starting point to the result about exterior angles requires some fairly abstract and formal reasoning (sum of interior and exterior angles is n(180); sum of interior angles is 180(n - 2); so, sum of exterior angles is 2(180)). This last reasoning is, of course, only as valid as the prior result.
Find the measures of the angles represented by a, b, c, and d. Explain your reasoning.

Students may reason in different orders. One solution might be:

∠a is vertical to the 90˚ angle. So, ∠x = 90˚.

∠b and ∠ 75˚ are supplemental. ∠b + ∠ 75˚ = 105˚ That makes ∠b = 105˚.

We know the measure of angles a and b. We know ∠ a+ ∠ b + ∠ c + 60˚ = 360.

So, ∠ 90˚ + ∠ 105˚ + ∠ c + 60˚ = 360

∠ c = 360 – 90 – 105 – 60

∠ c = 105˚
Are any of the labeled angles vertical? Supplementary? Complementary? Explain why.

Vertical: angles 90˚ and a, c and d. Each of these angles are “opposite” each other where two lines cross.

Note that there are 16 possible pairs vertical angles, but only 2 are labeled on the drawing.

Supplementary: b and 75˚. There angles add to 180˚.

Note that there are many possible pairs supplementary angles, but only 1 is labeled on the drawing.

Complementary: none of the given (labeled) angles are complementary (add to 90˚).
If possible, draw the triangle described. Explain if the triangle is unique or many triangles can fit the given information.
• (a). A triangle. Side = 2 in. Side = 1 in. ∠A = 75°.
One triangle is possible. A triangle with = 2 in., = 1 in., and ∠BAC = 75° will look like this:
There are many triangles that have ∠BAC = 75° and ∠ACB = 75°. All are similar to this with different length sides.
• (c). A triangle with angles 45° and 60° and one side of length 2 in.
There are many possible triangles with angles 45° and 60° and one side of length 2 in depending on where you locate the length of 2. One possible answer is:
• (d). A triangle with side KL = 1 in., side LM = 1.5 in., ∠L = 135°, and side KM = 1 in.

Cannot be constructed because once sides KL and LM are drawn with the given conditions, the distance from K to M is greater than 1 in. The given measurements do not fit the triangle inequality. Or, 1 + 1 > 1.5
Triangle with all sides of length 1.5 in. and all angles of 60°
One triangle is possible with all sides of length 1.5 in. and all angles of 60°.
• (a). A trapezoid PQRS. ∠P = 45°. ∠Q = 45°. Side = 1 in. Side = 2 in.
A trapezoid PQRS that has ∠QPS = 45°, ∠RQP = 45°, = 1 in., and = 2 in. will look like this:
• (b). A parallelogram ABCD with two sides of length 2 in., two sides of length 1 in., and angles of 60° and 120°
A parallelogram with two sides of length 2 in., two sides of length 1 in., and angles of 60° and 120° will look like this:
• (c). A quadrilateral EFGH. Side = 1 in. Side = 2 in. Side = 3 in. Side = 6 in.
Not possible. The sum of the three shortest side lengths must be longer than longest side length.
Which of these descriptions of a triangle ABC are directions that can be followed to draw exactly one shape?
No triangle is possible because the sum of the measures of the angles exceeds 180°.
In the parallelogram, find the measure of each numbered angle.
Angles 1, 3, and 5 are all 63°; angles 2 and  4 are both 117°.
True. Note: By our chosen definition, a trapezoid is a quadrilateral with one and only one pair of parallel sides.
• (g). Every quadrilateral is a parallelogram, a trapezoid, a rectangle, a rhombus, or a square.
Suppose you want to build a triangle with three angles measuring 60°.
(a). What do you think must be true of the side lengths?
All the side lengths would be equal. This would be a regular triangle.
• (c). Would this be a unique triangle?
No, there are many possible triangles with all angles measuring 60˚.

Nony writes the equation d = 6t to represent the distance in miles d that riders could travel in t hours at a speed of 6 miles per hour. Make a table that shows the distance traveled every hour, up to 5 hours, if riders travel at this constant speed.
Use the equations to fill in the quantities in a copy of the table.
The product of two numbers is 20. Find the value of n.
The coordinate grid below shows four polygons.
• (a). Give the coordinates of all vertices of each polygon.
(b). Use the coordinates to find the lengths of as many sides as you can.

1: horizontal = 4 units, vertical = 5 units

2: horizontal = 2 units, 4 units

3: vertical = 3 units, 3 units

4: horizontal = 2 units, 2 units, vertical = 3 units, 3 units
(c). Describe as precisely as possible each type of triangle or quadrilateral shown.
